awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Integration and Culture Change
awd_abstract_narration:
This doctoral dissertation project will investigate how states consolidate power and expand territorial control by transforming rural landscapes. Specifically, this project will track the formation of an imperial heartland in a region inhabited by politically fragmented agropastoral groups. Throughout history, state societies have transformed landscapes to naturalize their authority and discredit indigenous inhabitants by alleging mismanagement of natural resources and land. Although modern nation-states have established borders, disputed land claims still trigger conflict in many world regions and marginalized populations fight for sovereignty and territorial integrity by contesting state authority. This project looks at how states claim occupied territories and support expansion by transforming existing built environments and evaluates the efficacy of such endeavors over the long term. Archaeology is an excellent tool to track the successes and failures of political projects across expansive temporal and spatial scales. Using archaeological methods, this research will evaluate strategies of political sovereignty and identify contradictions that threaten the longevity of state societies, as manifested in the built environment. This project will be conducted in close collaboration with early-career researchers in Peru, providing training and capacity-building opportunities. In addition to forming the basis of dissertation research, two local archaeology students will conduct their thesis research in tandem with the project for the completion of their degrees.

The research team will analyze construction and landscape modification practices to understand how the Inkas established and managed their imperial heartland. Taking a long-term view over roughly half a millennium sheds light on the changing geopolitical conditions that shaped this region and the legacies of non-state political units. Ethnically diverse agropastoral groups settled in the Sacred Valley and began to build hilltop villages, agricultural terraces, and above-ground tombs across this mountainous landscape. Centuries later the Inka ethnic group had expanded political influence into the valley; their increasing presence was materialized in irrigated agricultural lands along the valley floor and administrative outposts in local (non-Inka) territories. By the Spanish invasion the valley had become foundational in supporting the Inkas’ sovereign ideology and political economy, which operated through estate systems and intensive landscape engineering projects. How did the Inkas’ strategies of expansion respond to the existing built environment? And how did the Inkas’ interventions impact local inhabitants and landscapes? This research will respond to these questions by defining the practices that shaped this landscape during the late pre-Hispanic period, including the standardization of architecture, centralization of agricultural systems, and diversity in mortuary practices. The contributions of this project include the development of an innovative research methodology that quantitatively measures variation in construction techniques to compare the sociopolitical context of production at local and regional scales. The data produced by this study can be compared with global cases to better understand human behavior including landscape modification practices and territoriality.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
How do autonomous communities coalesce into large, complex polities such as states and empires? And how do tensions, contradictions, and gaps in social integration precipitate political instability and decline? The project supported by this NSF award addressed these questions by examining the case of Inka state formation in the Cusco region, Peru (ca. 1000-1532 CE). The Inkas were an ethnic group that extended territorial control across the western length of South America by 1400 CE, forming the largest Indigenous empire in the Americas. The NSF-funded project investigated how the Inkas consolidated power prior to imperial expansion, while evaluating the agency of diverse ethnic groups that inhabited the region surrounding the Inka capital. This research focused on the Sacred Valley, which was an important part of the Inka imperial heartland where generations of Inka royal families established private estates.

For this project, co-PI Dr. Julia Earle used archaeological methods to analyze variation in the Sacred Valley's pre-contact built environment. Anthropological archaeology is well suited to investigate the processes and outcomes of political centralization by attending to multiscalar patterns over expansive time periods. The resultant insight gained from archaeological research can help develop solutions for improved sustainability and resilience of contemporary social systems into the future.

This study builds on three decades of regional archaeological surveys in Cusco that produced data on more than 3,000 sites within 2,370 km2. Using a novel methodological approach, this project documented and analyzed architecture and infrastructure at 34 Inka and local sites to compare social organization, religious practices, and agricultural production. Combined with the sites surveyed during the co-PI's pilot work (2019), the total dataset comprises 51 sites, representing a 9.1% sample of all late pre-contact sites registered by PI Covey's previous surveys in the Sacred Valley (2006, 2014). Given that architectural preservation is inconsistent across the study region, this is a purposive sample that privileges documented preservation.

The NSF-funded work produced maps, 3D models, and technical illustrations of architecture at 25 sites including local villages, royal estates, terrace systems, and mortuary complexes. The resultant dataset constitutes an invaluable record for future researchers, as preservation of this singular archaeological landscape is threatened by ongoing development associated with the growing tourist industry.

This research included radiocarbon dating of 33 grass inclusions embedded in mud mortar and plaster, offering insight into how architecture and construction practices varied over time. Inka rectangular buildings are distinguished from round buildings that are more typical of local vernacular traditions in the Sacred Valley. How did the Inkas develop distinctive state architecture? How did new forms of architecture spread across the Inka heartland? And how did local traditions of vernacular architecture change during Inka state formation? The answers to these questions provide insight into the development of power strategies and the impact of regional political shifts in rural communities.

The 33 samples analyzed for radiocarbon dates produced approximate dates of construction and use for pre-contact buildings and tombs. These dates indicate that hilltop villages were inhabited by the 800s to 900s, predating regional shifts associated with the collapse of the Wari Empire. By 1100, we observe the sudden appearance of new rectangular architecture in local villages, departing from vernacular structures in terms of the knowledge sets, aesthetics, and labor implicated in construction. Excavations at three sites in the study sample are planned to deepen insight into the use of these rectangular buildings and their relationship to later buildings built by the Inkas. The dates also show that vernacular construction in local villages continued into the 1400s under Inka occupation. However, a period of heightened village development may have occurred just prior in the 1300s.

This research involved collaboration with local descendant communities in the study region. Specifically, Earle worked with the community of Huama (Lamay District) to document traditional knowledge, including oral histories and house construction techniques. These research activities affirmed community interests while complementing archaeological data to model dimensions of the pre-contact past including cultural identity, interactions between cultural groups, and the social organization of technology.

This research provided ongoing training, capacity-building, and mentorship opportunities for early career researchers and students in Peru and the USA. It also supported collaborative partnerships between US-based and Peruvian researchers, as well as local community members. This research produced data for Earle's PhD dissertation (University of Texas at Austin) and the license thesis of archaeology students E. Franco Chavez and E. Champi Ojeda (National University of Saint Anthony the Abad in Cusco). The skills acquired from directing this project have enhanced Earle's abilities as a researcher and educator in preparation for her current academic appointment at Central Michigan University. Earle and colleagues continue disseminating the results of this research to varied public and scholarly audiences, while building on the project data through ongoing fieldwork and lab analysis in Cusco.
